comments:
CDT 200606040500, Eclipse 3.2RC7:

With this build I started getting StackOverflowError in Open Declaration. It happens when I select a method name in a method definition and press F3. If I select the same method identifier in a method call, navigation fails silently without an exception. The same sources moved to a small project (with some missing includes) don't produce a stack overflow, but F3 still fails. The classes I'm testing with do contain few nested classes and structs, although the exception happens on methods of the parent class. Aproximately 80% of methods cause exception, on the remaining 20% F3 fails silently.

java.lang.StackOverflowError
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPVisitor.getContainingScope(CPPVisitor.java:679)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPVisitor.getContainingScope(CPPVisitor.java:846)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createFunctionSpecialization(CPPTemplates.java:368)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createBinding(CPPTemplates.java:227)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPASTTemplateId.resolveBinding(CPPASTTemplateId.java:74)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPClassScope.getConstructors(CPPClassScope.java:260)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPClassScope.getBinding(CPPClassScope.java:233)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPSemantics.lookup(CPPSemantics.java:1019)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createFunctionSpecialization(CPPTemplates.java:376)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createBinding(CPPTemplates.java:227)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPASTTemplateId.resolveBinding(CPPASTTemplateId.java:74)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPClassScope.getConstructors(CPPClassScope.java:260)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPClassScope.getBinding(CPPClassScope.java:233)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPSemantics.lookup(CPPSemantics.java:1019)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createFunctionSpecialization(CPPTemplates.java:376)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createBinding(CPPTemplates.java:227)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPASTTemplateId.resolveBinding(CPPASTTemplateId.java:74)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPClassScope.getConstructors(CPPClassScope.java:260)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPClassScope.getBinding(CPPClassScope.java:233)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPSemantics.lookup(CPPSemantics.java:1019)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPTemplates.createFunctionSpecialization(CPPTemplates.java:376)

Wow, I'm seeing a lot of these, even in code that works the same way in 3.1 such as Open Declaration. I'll guess the logs were supressed.

I have strategy for these stack overflows that will serve as a workaround for 3.1.
The exection causes a popup dialog. How can log suppression explain its absense in previous builds?
I meant catching the exception and not letting it bubble up to the UI. I know we were guilty of that in the past.

I have a workaround that stops the exception happening. I now check in the CASTTemplateId whether were recursing in the resolveBinding method and return null if we are. I don't understand why we'd be recursing here so it's a safe bet and the tests still pass.

All this will get better once I have templates in the PDOM, hopefully for 3.1.1.
